Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Focus on what matters.hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#Cloud hashtag#AWSCommunity hashtag#CloudEngineer hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#TechCareer hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#AmazonWebServices hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#SoftwareDeveloper hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#dotnet hashtag#backend

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Focus on what matters.hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#Cloud hashtag#AWSCommunity hashtag#CloudEngineer hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#TechCareer hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#AmazonWebServices hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#SoftwareDeveloper hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#dotnet hashtag#backend

There are several reasons why companies may not always hire certified & qualified engineers, despite their credentials ğŸ¤”. Here are some key factors: hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Business hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Challenges1. Cost ConsiderationsHighly certified engineers often demand higher salaries, which some companies may not be willing or able to pay.Companies might prefer hiring less experienced engineers at a lower cost and providing on-the-job training.2. Experience vs. CertificationMany companies prioritize practical experience over certifications. A candidate with hands-on experience but no certification may be preferred over someone who is certified but lacks real-world problem-solving skills.Some hiring managers view certifications as "nice to have" but not as a substitute for actual project experience.3. Skills MismatchSome engineers may have certifications that are not aligned with the company's specific needs.A certification does not always guarantee that the candidate has the required soft skills, such as communication, teamwork, and adaptability.4. Industry-Specific NeedsCertain industries or companies prioritize proprietary tools and frameworks that are not covered by general certifications.Startups and fast-moving tech companies often value practical coding tests and problem-solving ability over certifications.5. Recruitment Bias & Hiring ProcessesSome HR departments and hiring managers may not fully understand the value of certifications.AI-driven or automated hiring systems may filter out qualified candidates due to rigid keyword matching.6. Internal Hiring and ReferralsMany companies prefer to hire internally or through referrals rather than going through the formal recruitment process.Internal promotions often take precedence over hiring external certified professionals.7. Lack of Hiring UrgencySome companies post job listings without an immediate hiring intention, leading to prolonged hiring cycles and making it seem like they are ignoring qualified candidates.8. Market SaturationIn fields like cybersecurity, software development, and DevOps, there are often more applicants than available jobs, leading to tough competition even for qualified candidates.What Can You Do?If you're facing challenges in getting hired despite your certifications, consider:Gaining more hands-on experience through freelance projects or open-source contributions.Networking with professionals and attending industry events.Tailoring your resume to highlight real-world projects rather than just certifications.Improving soft skills like communication and leadership, which many employers value highly.Would you like help in optimizing your job search strategy?

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Focus on what matters.hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#Cloud hashtag#AWSCommunity hashtag#CloudEngineer hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#TechCareer hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#AmazonWebServices hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#SoftwareDeveloper hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#dotnet hashtag#backend

There are several reasons why companies may not always hire certified & qualified engineers, despite their credentials ğŸ¤”. Here are some key factors: hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Business hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Challenges1. Cost ConsiderationsHighly certified engineers often demand higher salaries, which some companies may not be willing or able to pay.Companies might prefer hiring less experienced engineers at a lower cost and providing on-the-job training.2. Experience vs. CertificationMany companies prioritize practical experience over certifications. A candidate with hands-on experience but no certification may be preferred over someone who is certified but lacks real-world problem-solving skills.Some hiring managers view certifications as "nice to have" but not as a substitute for actual project experience.3. Skills MismatchSome engineers may have certifications that are not aligned with the company's specific needs.A certification does not always guarantee that the candidate has the required soft skills, such as communication, teamwork, and adaptability.4. Industry-Specific NeedsCertain industries or companies prioritize proprietary tools and frameworks that are not covered by general certifications.Startups and fast-moving tech companies often value practical coding tests and problem-solving ability over certifications.5. Recruitment Bias & Hiring ProcessesSome HR departments and hiring managers may not fully understand the value of certifications.AI-driven or automated hiring systems may filter out qualified candidates due to rigid keyword matching.6. Internal Hiring and ReferralsMany companies prefer to hire internally or through referrals rather than going through the formal recruitment process.Internal promotions often take precedence over hiring external certified professionals.7. Lack of Hiring UrgencySome companies post job listings without an immediate hiring intention, leading to prolonged hiring cycles and making it seem like they are ignoring qualified candidates.8. Market SaturationIn fields like cybersecurity, software development, and DevOps, there are often more applicants than available jobs, leading to tough competition even for qualified candidates.What Can You Do?If you're facing challenges in getting hired despite your certifications, consider:Gaining more hands-on experience through freelance projects or open-source contributions.Networking with professionals and attending industry events.Tailoring your resume to highlight real-world projects rather than just certifications.Improving soft skills like communication and leadership, which many employers value highly.Would you like help in optimizing your job search strategy?

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. There are several reasons why companies may not always hire certified & qualified engineers, despite their credentials ğŸ¤”. Here are some key factors: hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Business hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Challenges1. Cost ConsiderationsHighly certified engineers often demand higher salaries, which some companies may not be willing or able to pay.Companies might prefer hiring less experienced engineers at a lower cost and providing on-the-job training.2. Experience vs. CertificationMany companies prioritize practical experience over certifications. A candidate with hands-on experience but no certification may be preferred over someone who is certified but lacks real-world problem-solving skills.Some hiring managers view certifications as "nice to have" but not as a substitute for actual project experience.3. Skills MismatchSome engineers may have certifications that are not aligned with the company's specific needs.A certification does not always guarantee that the candidate has the required soft skills, such as communication, teamwork, and adaptability.4. Industry-Specific NeedsCertain industries or companies prioritize proprietary tools and frameworks that are not covered by general certifications.Startups and fast-moving tech companies often value practical coding tests and problem-solving ability over certifications.5. Recruitment Bias & Hiring ProcessesSome HR departments and hiring managers may not fully understand the value of certifications.AI-driven or automated hiring systems may filter out qualified candidates due to rigid keyword matching.6. Internal Hiring and ReferralsMany companies prefer to hire internally or through referrals rather than going through the formal recruitment process.Internal promotions often take precedence over hiring external certified professionals.7. Lack of Hiring UrgencySome companies post job listings without an immediate hiring intention, leading to prolonged hiring cycles and making it seem like they are ignoring qualified candidates.8. Market SaturationIn fields like cybersecurity, software development, and DevOps, there are often more applicants than available jobs, leading to tough competition even for qualified candidates.What Can You Do?If you're facing challenges in getting hired despite your certifications, consider:Gaining more hands-on experience through freelance projects or open-source contributions.Networking with professionals and attending industry events.Tailoring your resume to highlight real-world projects rather than just certifications.Improving soft skills like communication and leadership, which many employers value highly.Would you like help in optimizing your job search strategy?

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Focus on what matters.hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#Cloud hashtag#AWSCommunity hashtag#CloudEngineer hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#TechCareer hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#AmazonWebServices hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#SoftwareDeveloper hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#dotnet hashtag#backend

There are several reasons why companies may not always hire certified & qualified engineers, despite their credentials ğŸ¤”. Here are some key factors: hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Business hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Challenges1. Cost ConsiderationsHighly certified engineers often demand higher salaries, which some companies may not be willing or able to pay.Companies might prefer hiring less experienced engineers at a lower cost and providing on-the-job training.2. Experience vs. CertificationMany companies prioritize practical experience over certifications. A candidate with hands-on experience but no certification may be preferred over someone who is certified but lacks real-world problem-solving skills.Some hiring managers view certifications as "nice to have" but not as a substitute for actual project experience.3. Skills MismatchSome engineers may have certifications that are not aligned with the company's specific needs.A certification does not always guarantee that the candidate has the required soft skills, such as communication, teamwork, and adaptability.4. Industry-Specific NeedsCertain industries or companies prioritize proprietary tools and frameworks that are not covered by general certifications.Startups and fast-moving tech companies often value practical coding tests and problem-solving ability over certifications.5. Recruitment Bias & Hiring ProcessesSome HR departments and hiring managers may not fully understand the value of certifications.AI-driven or automated hiring systems may filter out qualified candidates due to rigid keyword matching.6. Internal Hiring and ReferralsMany companies prefer to hire internally or through referrals rather than going through the formal recruitment process.Internal promotions often take precedence over hiring external certified professionals.7. Lack of Hiring UrgencySome companies post job listings without an immediate hiring intention, leading to prolonged hiring cycles and making it seem like they are ignoring qualified candidates.8. Market SaturationIn fields like cybersecurity, software development, and DevOps, there are often more applicants than available jobs, leading to tough competition even for qualified candidates.What Can You Do?If you're facing challenges in getting hired despite your certifications, consider:Gaining more hands-on experience through freelance projects or open-source contributions.Networking with professionals and attending industry events.Tailoring your resume to highlight real-world projects rather than just certifications.Improving soft skills like communication and leadership, which many employers value highly.Would you like help in optimizing your job search strategy?

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Focus on what matters.hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#Cloud hashtag#AWSCommunity hashtag#CloudEngineer hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#TechCareer hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#AmazonWebServices hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#SoftwareDeveloper hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#dotnet hashtag#backend

There are several reasons why companies may not always hire certified & qualified engineers, despite their credentials ğŸ¤”. Here are some key factors: hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Business hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Challenges1. Cost ConsiderationsHighly certified engineers often demand higher salaries, which some companies may not be willing or able to pay.Companies might prefer hiring less experienced engineers at a lower cost and providing on-the-job training.2. Experience vs. CertificationMany companies prioritize practical experience over certifications. A candidate with hands-on experience but no certification may be preferred over someone who is certified but lacks real-world problem-solving skills.Some hiring managers view certifications as "nice to have" but not as a substitute for actual project experience.3. Skills MismatchSome engineers may have certifications that are not aligned with the company's specific needs.A certification does not always guarantee that the candidate has the required soft skills, such as communication, teamwork, and adaptability.4. Industry-Specific NeedsCertain industries or companies prioritize proprietary tools and frameworks that are not covered by general certifications.Startups and fast-moving tech companies often value practical coding tests and problem-solving ability over certifications.5. Recruitment Bias & Hiring ProcessesSome HR departments and hiring managers may not fully understand the value of certifications.AI-driven or automated hiring systems may filter out qualified candidates due to rigid keyword matching.6. Internal Hiring and ReferralsMany companies prefer to hire internally or through referrals rather than going through the formal recruitment process.Internal promotions often take precedence over hiring external certified professionals.7. Lack of Hiring UrgencySome companies post job listings without an immediate hiring intention, leading to prolonged hiring cycles and making it seem like they are ignoring qualified candidates.8. Market SaturationIn fields like cybersecurity, software development, and DevOps, there are often more applicants than available jobs, leading to tough competition even for qualified candidates.What Can You Do?If you're facing challenges in getting hired despite your certifications, consider:Gaining more hands-on experience through freelance projects or open-source contributions.Networking with professionals and attending industry events.Tailoring your resume to highlight real-world projects rather than just certifications.Improving soft skills like communication and leadership, which many employers value highly.Would you like help in optimizing your job search strategy?

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

You donâ€™t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive wayâ€”beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS coursesâ€”I would focus on these:âœ… EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) â€“ Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.âœ… ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate â€“ A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.âœ… S3 (Simple Storage Service) â€“ Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.âœ… RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB â€“ RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.âœ… Lambda â€“ A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.âœ… API Gateway â€“ A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.âœ… CloudWatch â€“ A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.âœ… IAM (Identity and Access Management) â€“ AWSâ€™s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.âœ… SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) â€“ SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and youâ€™ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you donâ€™t need to know it all to be effective. Focus on what matters.hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#Cloud hashtag#AWSCommunity hashtag#CloudEngineer hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#TechCareer hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#AmazonWebServices hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#SoftwareDeveloper hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#dotnet hashtag#backend
